conclusion: To find the radius r_max of a drop just before it separates from the nozzle, consider the forces acting on the droplet.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force overcomes the surface tension force.
The gravitational force acting on the droplet is F_g = (4/3)πr^3ρg.
ρ is the density of water, g is the acceleration due to gravity, r is the radius of the droplet.
The surface tension force is F_surface = σ * 2πr.
σ is the surface tension of water, 2πr is the circumference of the droplet at the point of separation.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force equals the surface tension force: (4/3)πr^3ρg = σ * 2πr.
Simplify the equation by canceling out common terms (πr): (4/3)r^2ρg = 2σ.
Rearrange to solve for r: r^2 = (3σ)/(2ρg).
The radius r_max of a drop just before it separates from the nozzle is r_max = sqrt((3σ)/(2ρg)).
This expression gives the maximum radius of the droplet before it detaches due to the balance between gravitational and surface tension forces.
